summary: This document is internal FBI correspondence from January 10, 2020, discussing the status of surveillance video from outside Jeffrey Epstein's cell during his July 2019 suicide attempt. It reveals that the video was stored on a corrupted DVR, all recovery efforts failed, and prosecutors had been aware of the issue since November 2019. The correspondence includes forwarded news reports about the video's deletion and the resulting conspiracy theories.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The document discusses the missing surveillance video from outside his jail cell during his first suicide attempt in July 2019.

persons.name: Kenneth Karas
persons.context: Prosecutors informed him that prison authorities inadvertently deleted the surveillance video from outside Epstein's cell.

persons.name: Tartaglione
persons.context: Epstein's cellmate at the time of the July 2019 suicide attempt; his attorney requested preservation of the cell video.

connections.description: They were housed together in the same cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in July 2019.

events.title: Epstein's First Suicide Attempt
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found on the floor of his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center with a strip of bedsheet around his neck in an apparent suicide attempt.

events.title: Attorney Request for Video Preservation
events.description: An attorney for Epstein's cellmate, Tartaglione, asked the MCC to preserve surveillance video from outside their cell from the night of the suicide attempt.

events.title: AUSAs and Investigative Team Informed
events.description: The Assistant US Attorneys and the investigative team were made aware that the surveillance video from Epstein's cell was corrupted and unrecoverable.

events.title: Prosecutors Disclose Video Deletion to Judge
events.description: Prosecutors told US District Judge Kenneth Karas that prison authorities had inadvertently deleted the surveillance video from outside Epstein's cell due to a computer system error preserving footage from the wrong cell.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York
keyFacts: Surveillance video from outside Jeffrey Epstein's cell during his July 23, 2019 suicide attempt was stored on a corrupted DVR and all FBI recovery efforts were unsuccessful.
The video was mistakenly not preserved because the MCC computer system listed an incorrect cell number for Epstein's cellmate, leading staff to preserve unrelated footage.
The Assistant US Attorneys and investigative team had been aware of the video corruption issue since November 2019.
The disclosure of the missing video was likely to revive conspiracy theories suggesting Epstein was murdered to prevent him from discussing his activities.
The internal FBI correspondence is dated January 10, 2020, and discusses validating reports about the alleged missing video.
